item.title: Goals of Health Psychology
item.description: Goals of Health Psychology Promote Healthy Behaviour & Reduce Illnessess Manage health crisis 1. Someone chronically ill 2. Are trained to administer mental health first aid 3.

item.title: Bowlby's Attachment Theory
item.description: Bowlby’s Attachment Theory [[attachment]] to a caregiver over the first year of life has important consequences throughout the life span.

item.title: Ecological Theory
item.description: Ecological Theory these place emphasis on the environmental factors Bronfenbrenner’s ecological theory Urie Bronfenbrenner proposed the ‘Ecological Systems Theory’ based on dynamic interactions that environments have on the child.

item.title: Erik Erikson's Psychosocial Stages
item.description: Erikson’s Psychosocial Theory like Freud’s theory, focuses on unconscious. But instead of sexual, focuses on social aspects connection, attribution, love, care

item.title: Ethological Theory
item.description: Ethological Theory says behavior is strongly influenced by biology and is tied to evolution characterized by critical or sensitive periods or specific time frames during which certain experiences can have a long-lasting influence

item.title: Information processing theory
item.description: 3. Information processing theory No structure or stages; continuous/gradual monitoring, manipulating, strategizing information #todo

item.title: Lorenz's Ethological Theory
item.description: Lorenz’s Ethological Theory, Imprinting Konrad Lorenz, a zoologist studied the behavior of greylag geese, which will follow their mothers as soon as they hatch

item.description: ![[meta/external/Expert on Mental Illness Reveals Her Own Struggle - The New York Times#Highlights|Expert on Mental Illness Reveals Her Own Struggle - The New York Times]]

item.title: Mary Ainsworth's Attachment Theory
item.description: Mary Ainsworth’s Attachment Theory emphasized the importance of early relationships built on John Bowlby’s work [[Bowlby’s Attachment Theory]] Strange Situation assessment a researcher observes a child’s reactions when a mother briefly leaves her child alone in an unfamiliar room.

item.title: Piaget's Cognitive Theory of Development
item.description: Piaget accd to him, the way they think, not how much they know, decides their cognitive development children actively construct their understanding of the world

item.title: Vygotsky's Sociocultural Cognitive Method
item.description: Vygotsky’s Sociocultural Cognitive Method emphasizes on how culture and social interaction mould cognitive development child’s development as inseparable from social and cultural activities

item.title: Narcissism of Small Differences
item.description: in psychoanalysis, the narcissism of small differences is the idea that the more a relationship or community shares commonalities, the more likely the people in it are to engage in interpersonal feuds and mutual ridicule because of hypersensitivity to minor differences perceived in each other

item.title: Groups
item.description: What are groups? Types of groups flowchart A--B A--C A(Groups) B(Organized) C(Unorganized)

item.title: Schools of Psychology
item.description: Behaviourism Determinism [[Existential]] [[Humanistic]]

item.title: Social Psychology
item.description: Definition scientific study that explains how the presence of others people, whether real, imaginary, or implied affects our thinking and behaviour - [[Gordon Allport]] 🔧!

item.title: Parable of the Polygons
item.description: Parable of the Polygons Metadata Author: [ncase.me] Title: Parable of the Polygons Reference: https://ncase.me/polygons/ Highlights Small individual bias can lead to large collective bias.

item.title: ptsd
item.description: PTSD (posttraumatic stress disorder) is a mental health problem that some people develop after experiencing or witnessing a life-threatening event, like combat, a natural disaster, a car accident, or sexual assault.

item.title: Broken windows theory
item.description: theory was introduced in a 1982 article by social scientists James Q. Wilson and George L. Kelling the broken windows theory states that visible signs of crime, anti-social behaviour and civil disorder create an urban environment that encourages further crime and disorder, including serious crimes.

item.title: cognitive bias
item.description: “a systematic pattern of deviation from norm or rationality in judgment” cognitive biases may sometimes lead to perceptual distortion, inaccurate judgment, illogical interpretation, and irrationality

item.title: algorithms
item.description: Algorithm: A step-by-step procedure or a set of instructions that leads to a desired outcome or a solution to a problem.

item.title: heuristics
item.description: Heuristic: A rule of thumb or a shortcut that helps solve a problem or make a decision quickly and efficiently.

item.title: Barnum Effect
item.description: The Barnum Effect is when people believe that vague and general statements about their personality or behaviour are accurate and personal to them.

item.title: Late Adulthood
item.description: Physical Development Brain shrinks; 5-10% loss in mass Brain volume decreases (up to 15%) Immune System Decline Low level of protein linked to decrease in T cells

item.title: Middle Adulthood
item.description: Change in physical appearance skin begins to wrinkle and sag because of a loss of fat and collagen in underlying tissues hair thins and greys pigmentation Height and weight

item.title: Perinatal Period
item.description: During or around birth

item.title: Sternberg's Triangular Theory of Love
item.description: Sternberg’s Triangular Theory of Love Intimacy Passion Commitment Non-love Liking/friendship ✔ Infatuated love ✔ Empty love ✔ Romantic love ✔ ✔ Companionate love ✔ ✔ Fatuous love ✔ ✔ Consummate love ✔ ✔ ✔

item.title: Developmental Research
item.description: Types of developmental research designs Cross-sectional design A cross-sectional study compares the behaviors of different age groups at a single time point.

item.title: Normative vs Idiographic
item.description: In [[Introduction to Life Span Development|Developmental Psychology]], patterns of change can be - Normative Idiographic focuses on what we share in common focuses on individual differences “normal” or typical changes different for everyone milestones for babies, for example individual variations outside of the range of normative dev and why

item.title: Self Concept Scale
item.description: Introduction What is self concept? Self concept = collection of beliefs, self-perceptions, and cognitive schema about onself self concept is a framework that influences our motives, emotional states, abilities, etc

item.title: Aaron T Beck
item.description: ![[images/Aaron T Beck.jpg|100]] Aaron T Beck (July 18, 1921 – November 1, 2021) - influential psychiatrist who is regarded as the father of cognitive therapy and cognitive behavioural therapy.

item.title: Beck's Depression Inventory
item.description: made by [[Aaron T Beck]] published in 1961 Introduction 21-item, self-report rating inventory measures characteristic attitudes and symptoms of depression

item.title: FIRO B
item.description: Intro William Schultz 1950s 54 item questionnaire B = Behaviour three dimensions - inclusion, control, affection Inclusion assesses the degree to which a person associates with others.

item.title: Midlife Crisis
item.description: occurs usually around 40 - 60 Identity, role, self-doubt regarding : professional life achievements family psychological aspects > physical aspects in terms of effect

item.description: Low birth weight - below 5.5 pounds - very low weight - extremely low weight - below 2.5 preterm infants small for date (aka small for gestational age)

item.title: Theories of Human Development
item.description: flowchart LR A(Theories of Human Development) subgraph psychoanalytic B(Psychosocial Theory by Erik Erikson) C(Psychosexual by Freud) end subgraph cognitive E(Piaget's Cognitive Dev) F(Vygotsky's Social Cognitive) G(Information Processing Theory) end subgraph etho S(Lorenz's Ethological) V(Bowlby's Attachment) R(Ainsworth's Attachment) end A---etho A---Q(Urie's Ecological) A---psychoanalytic A---cognitive see also: [[Introduction to Life Span Development#Perspectives / Key issues in Lifespan Development|Key issues in Lifespan Development]]

item.title: Core Tenets
item.description: Emotions are good. [[All emotions are valid]]. They always are. All emotions, including anger. [[Laziness |You are not Lazy]] You are not overreacting.

item.title: Cognitive Distortions
item.description: What are cognitive distortions? They are patterns of thinking that are negative and “irrational”. Unhelpful thinking patterns. Again, reminder that these thought patterns probably evolved as a response to trauma, so please be kind to yourself.

item.title: Spoon Theory
item.description: “ The Spoon Theory”, a personal story by Christine Miserandino, is popular among many people dealing with chronic illness. It describes perfectly this idea of limited energy, using “spoons” as a unit of energy.

item.title: Ikea Effect
item.description: TLDR; a [[cognitive bias]] in which consumers place a disproportionately high value on products they partially created. Labor leads to love when labor leads to successful or satisfactory results.

item.title: Behaviour
item.description: broad definition - any action of an organism that changes its relationship to its environment. Behavior provides outputs from the organism to the environment.

item.description: etymology - the word couvade comes from the Breton word couver, which means to brood, hatch, or incubate Couvade syndrome is also called sympathetic pregnancy.

item.title: Zeigarnik Effect
item.description: “An individual remembers the task until it is done” postulates that people remember unfinished or interrupted tasks better than completed tasks

item.title: Zone of Proximal Development
item.description: Space between what a learner can do without assistance and what a learner can do with adult guidance or in collaboration with more capable peers !
